description:
This changes the way the `units` keyword argument of `add_field` works in two small hopefully important and hopefully useful way.

First, field definitions that return data with incorrect units will now raise a more informative error, including the name of the field that has unit issues and a more complete explanation why the units don't make sense.

Second, fields functions that return raw ndarray data will now be interpreted as dimensionless.  Before, the ndarray was silently cast to whichever units were specified in the units string.

Last, I've added `units='auto'`, which automatically determines the units based on the units of the return value of the field definition.  This is useful if you don't know the units of your field ahead of time.

I've added new tests and docs.  This should be ready for review and hopefully to be merged.
title: Improved semantics for derived field units

content.raw: Doesn't the first change in the notebook remove some of the sanity-checking that the units system provides? I could see myself making a mistake in a more complicated field definition that would be caught in the old way, but not in the new way.
content.html: Doesn't the first change in the notebook remove some of the sanity-checking that the units system provides? I could see myself making a mistake in a more complicated field definition that would be caught in the old way, but not in the new way.

pullrequest.title: Improved semantics for derived field units

content.raw: It does, that's why it logs a warning.  I was initially hesitant about doing this, but I had three people tell me on IRC that they want it to work that way.  I think Kacper said "he wants yt to think for him", posing the case where the field returns some complicated units that you don't necessarily know ahead of time.
content.html: It does, that's why it logs a warning. I was initially hesitant about doing this, but I had three people tell me on IRC that they want it to work that way. I think Kacper said "he wants yt to think for him", posing the case where the field returns some complicated units that you don't necessarily know ahead of time.

pullrequest.title: Improved semantics for derived field units

content.raw:
Heh, I was so used to skipping the duplicate field warnings that I didn't actually see that.

I guess I feel like if your field is so complicated that you  don't know what dimensions it has in principle, what makes you think you coded the definition right? But a warning should good enough I guess.
content.html:
Heh, I was so used to skipping the duplicate field warnings that I didn't actually see that.

I guess I feel like if your field is so complicated that you don't know what dimensions it has in principle, what makes you think you coded the definition right? But a warning should good enough I guess.

pullrequest.title: Improved semantics for derived field units

content.raw:
Honestly I agree with you, but this appears to be a big pain point that a few people don't like.

If others agree with Andrew, I'm very happy to revert it to the old behavior but with an improved error message.  Would love to hear people's thoughts, for or against.
content.html:
Honestly I agree with you, but this appears to be a big pain point that a few people don't like.

If others agree with Andrew, I'm very happy to revert it to the old behavior but with an improved error message. Would love to hear people's thoughts, for or against.

content.raw: I'll also note that you can still specify the units to get runtime dimensionality checking, this change just makes it optional.
content.html: I'll also note that you can still specify the units to get runtime dimensionality checking, this change just makes it optional.

pullrequest.title: Improved semantics for derived field units

content.raw:
Hm, my thinking during the discussion was more along the lines of "what to
do when a YTArray is returned" and allowing a particular value for the
declared units to be set to avoid errors if the YTArray units didn't match.
This would retain most or all of the sanity checking.
content.html: Hm, my thinking during the discussion was more along the lines of "what to do when a YTArray is returned" and allowing a particular value for the declared units to be set to avoid errors if the YTArray units didn't match. This would retain most or all of the sanity checking.

content.raw: I'm sorry, can you elaborate a bit more what you mean here? Maybe a tiny example will help me understand.
content.html: I'm sorry, can you elaborate a bit more what you mean here? Maybe a tiny example will help me understand.

pullrequest.title: Improved semantics for derived field units

content.html:
Something like this:

@yt.derived_field(name="energy", units="unknown")
def _energy(field, data):
    return data["some_weird_energy"] + data["some_other_energy"]

Whatever units it came back in would be the right units.

I do not like casting and applying all ndarrays; we already have functionality in apply_units to do something similar. This would also be safe, since we would not be coercing units, we'd just be allowing them to propagate.

pullrequest.title: Improved semantics for derived field units

content.raw:
This is actually how `units='auto'` fields work under the hood.  They only get their units set based on the first return value from the field function, not every time.

I'll update the comment here to make that clearer.
content.html:
This is actually how units='auto' fields work under the hood. They only get their units set based on the first return value from the field function, not every time.

I'll update the comment here to make that clearer.
